docs.lead_paragraph: As the Democratic presidential candidates put the economy at the front and center of their campaigns, their differences boil down to a handful of issues: how much to roll back tax cuts, how much to raise spending, how much to reduce deficits and how to approach trade. But the dividing lines are often subtle. The rival platforms can look like different sides of a Rubik's Cube: varying combinations of the same basic proposals.

headline.main: Democratic Candidates Differ On Economy, but Often Subtly

docs.abstract: Article in series The Issues discusses differences between Democratic presidential rivals on economic and fiscal matters; dividing lines are often subtle, with varying combinations of proposals on how much to roll back tax cuts and raise spending and how to approach deficits and other trade issues; all would repeal some of Pres Bush's tax cuts, most propose large new health care programs and none have fully explained how they would steer federal budget back from Bush deficits to Clinton-era surpluses; differences are in tone toward business, with Joseph Lieberman favoring more of Bill Clinton's business-friendly approach, and others like Richard Gephardt and Howard Dean calling for more activist government; Gephardt voted against Nafta agreement; Dean has gone back and forth on trade; table comparing views of all; photos (M)
docs.snippet: As the Democratic presidential candidates put the economy at the front and center of their campaigns, their differences boil down to a handful of issues: how much to roll back tax cuts, how much to raise spending, how much to reduce deficits and how...

docs.lead_paragraph: Ephedra, the herbal supplement that has been linked to heart attack, stroke and sudden death -- including that of a pitcher in the Baltimore Orioles organization -- poses an ''an unreasonable risk to the public health'' and will be banned, Bush administration officials said on Tuesday. The ban is the first time that the Food and Drug Administration has removed a dietary supplement from the market since 1994, when Congress passed a law severely restricting the agency's authority to regulate herbal products. It will not take effect for several months.

headline.main: U.S. TO PROHIBIT SUPPLEMENT TIED TO HEALTH RISKS

docs.abstract: Bush administration says that ephedra, herbal supplement linked to heart attack, stroke and sudden death, poses 'unreasonable risk' to public health and will be banned; action is first ban of dietary supplement since 1994, when Congress severely restricted FDA's authority to regulate herbal products; ban will not take effect for several months but Sec Tommy G Thompson strongly urges consumers to stop using product taken to help lose weight or enhance athletic performance; ephedra is linked to death of Baltimore Orioles pitcher Steve Bechler; photos; trade groups say they welcome action after so much bad publicity and hope it will avert wider regulation of supplements; Comr Mark B McClellan says FDA first tried to restrict ephedra in 1997 but GAO deemed evidence insufficient (M)
docs.snippet: Ephedra, the herbal supplement that has been linked to heart attack, stroke and sudden death -- including that of a pitcher in the Baltimore Orioles organization -- poses an ''an unreasonable risk to the public health'' and will be banned, Bush...

docs.lead_paragraph: Calling himself a Vermont Yankee, Howard Dean pitched a populist economic message on Tuesday in this depressed coastal town where 563 jobs disappeared when a steel plant closed in October and where the county unemployment rate is 14.5 percent. ''It doesn't matter if you're North or South: if you're from a rural state and you need jobs, you're an American,'' Dr. Dean told several hundred people outside a historic mansion. ''That's good enough for me and I hope it's good enough for you.''

headline.main: Pocketbook Issues at Top of Agenda as Democrats Swarm South Carolina

docs.abstract: Howard Dean pitches populist economic message as he campaigns in South Carolina for Democratic presidential nomination; photo; rivals Richard Gephardt and Wesley Clark follow suit in comments to Southerners hard pressed by manufacturing losses (M)
docs.snippet: Calling himself a Vermont Yankee, Howard Dean pitched a populist economic message on Tuesday in this depressed coastal town where 563 jobs disappeared when a steel plant closed in October and where the county unemployment rate is 14.5 percent.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Quietly and painfully, most states are choosing to crimp the health-care safety net for their poorest and most politically defenseless residents. An ominous new study shows that up to 1.6 million impoverished and working-poor Americans -- at least a third of them children -- have been deliberately knocked from publicly financed health care programs in the last two years. Officials in 34 states are opting to slash Medicaid and poor children's health insurance coverage as a path of least resistance to the balanced budgets mandated by law. States have raised poverty standards beyond federal requirements, increased bureaucratic delays and even shut down children's health programs entirely to keep entitled poor people off the rolls. For each dollar thereby saved in the state budget, statehouses are losing $4 to $7 in federal aid. Yet more such counterproductive ''economizing'' can be expected next year, according to the study, by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a government watchdog group.

headline.main: The Budget Politics of Being Poor

docs.abstract: Editorial on new finding that up to 1.6 million impoverished and working-poor Americans, at least one-third of them children, have been cut from publicly financed health care programs in last two years as 34 states opt to slash Medicaid and other health coverage in face of budget deficits

docs.lead_paragraph: Philadelphia officials want department heads to cut about 8 percent of their budgets, on average, to close a projected $150 million shortfall in the coming fiscal year. With revenues expected to remain flat and pension and health care costs rising, the cuts are needed to balance the $3.2 billion budget that begins July 1, officials said. The departments were asked to cut a combined $115 million, while Mayor John Street's administration will seek $35 million more in savings. Officials said they might consider self-insurance to contain rising health costs or consolidate staffs when possible.

headline.main: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: City Will Try To Close Budget Gap

docs.abstract: Department heads in Philadelphia are asked to cut about 8 percent of their budgets to close projected $150 million budget deficit (S)
docs.snippet: Philadelphia officials want department heads to cut about 8 percent of their budgets, on average, to close a projected $150 million shortfall in the coming fiscal year. With revenues expected to remain flat and pension and health care costs rising,...

docs.lead_paragraph: A complex operation called spinal fusion has emerged as the treatment of choice for many kinds of unrelenting back pain. A quarter million of the procedures, in which metal rods are screwed into the spine to stabilize it, were performed this year in the United States, three times as many as a decade ago. But a number of researchers say there is little scientific evidence to show that for most patients, spinal fusion works any better than a simpler operation, the laminectomy. And laminectomies get patients out of the hospital and back to their daily routine much faster. Some people, experts add, would be better off with no surgery at all. Even doctors who favor fusions say that more research is needed on their benefits.

headline.main: An Operation to Ease Back Pain Bolsters the Bottom Line, Too

docs.abstract: Complex operation called spinal fusion has emerged as treatment of choice for many kinds of unrelenting back pain, with quarter of a million procedures performed this year in US; several researchers say there is little scientific evidence that spinal fusion, in which metal rods are screwed into spine, works any better for most patients than simpler laminectomy, in which same part of bone, lamina, is removed but without hardware; photos; diagram; critics say difference is money, with surgeons and hospitals getting up to four times as much reimbursement; Medicare spent some $750 million last year on spinal fusions; Medronic, which makes sinal hardware, has been subject of charges of paying kickbacks to surgeons (M)

byline.original: By REED ABELSON and MELODY PETERSEN

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: President Bush and Howard Dean may indeed come from strikingly similar backgrounds (front page, Dec. 28). But the most revealing comparison between the two men is not of their privileged upbringing but of what they did with it. George W. Bush used his family's influence and wealth to win personal favors and to build a business enterprise from which he profited. He continues to this day to advance his interests by propagating policies favoring the very well-to-do.
docs.abstract: Marius Meland letter on Dec 28 review of Howard Dean's career notes Pres Bush used his priviledged upbringing for personal gain, while Dean is driven to help less fortunate
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    President Bush and Howard Dean may indeed come from strikingly similar backgrounds (front page, Dec. 28). But the most revealing comparison between the two men is not of their privileged upbringing but of what they did with it.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: The year was 1958, I was 16 and my mother was lying in a hospital bed connected to all sorts of tubes and was dying of cancer. As her life slipped away, a nurse slapped an oxygen mask on her face and asked me to hold it. There was no chance for either of us to say goodbye or ''I love you.'' I carry this medicalized memory of my mother's death with me to this day. I am hardly alone. Cicely Saunders, the founder of the first modern hospice, said, ''How people die remains in the memories of those who live on.''

headline.main: Facing Up to the Inevitable, in Search of a Good Death

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody article discusses caring for dying patients and their families; Rose Virani, City of Hope National Medical Center research specialist, and writer Dalia Sofer note in article appearing in American Journal of Nursing that many deaths are made more chaotic by poor communication and over- or under-treating patients; American Geriatrics Society lists nine important factors for quality care at life's end; factors address care before and after death for patient and family; Elizabeth Ford Pitorak, Hospice Institute of Hospice of the Western Reserve (Cleveland, Ohio) director, describes process of active dying or total body failure and outlines specific ways to help patient through process; role of doctors in caring for patients approaching death discussed; photos (L)

keywords.value: CITY OF HOPE NATIONAL MEDICAL CENTER

docs.lead_paragraph: The 260 layoff letters are already written. They have been distributed to supervisors and department heads at Nassau County's hard-pressed health care provider, and come Tuesday morning, they will be parceled out to employees, according to union officials. The layoffs represent the first round of major job cuts as the Nassau County Health Care Corporation tries to close its gaping budget deficits. Officials at the health agency said the layoffs would probably continue through the coming year, and could affect as many as 600 people -- about 15 percent of the corporation's work force of 4,000 people.

headline.main: 260 Layoffs Set by Nassau Health Care Corp.

docs.abstract: Nassau County Health Care Corp is set to layoff 260 hospital and nursing home workers; may lay off as many as 340 more over 2004; is trying to close $14 million budget deficit; photo (M)
